newsitem.title: FRANCE: French rail unions raise threat of Oct. 17 strike.
newsitem.headline: French rail unions raise threat of Oct. 17 strike.

text.p: The two most powerful unions in France's SNCF state railroads raised the threat of a strike along with civil service unions on Oct. 17 after a meeting between a rail staff committee and SNCF management on Tuesday.

The Communist-led CGT union said after the meeting it was proposing talks among rail workers and other unions on the possibility of a "day of action" on Oct. 17 amid concern over staff cuts and other worries about the SNCF's future.

Rail workers spearheaded a crippling 24-day strike and wider unrest late last year when the centre-right government of Prime Minister Alain Juppe proposed ending their early pension rights -- proposals which have since been scrapped.

The gripe this time, over programmed cuts in staffing levels and a modernisation plan which involves taking huge debts off the SNCF's hands, is harder to measure in terms of its potential to mobilise the railworkers themselves or wider public support.

Bruno Dalberto of the Socialist CFDT union said after the meeting on Tuesday that his union would decide after further internal talks on Wednesday whether to join a day of action on Oct. 17, and could well do so.

Dalberto, whose union has opposed a reform and debt relief plan for the SNCF since it was unveiled in June, said a one-day strike at the same time as civil service unions had always been on the cards as far as his union was concerned.
"We had already said it was probable that we'd join the others in the civil service on Oct. 17," Dalberto said.
